In [[Canada]], an '''allophone''' is a resident, whose [[mother tongue]] or [[home language]] is neither [[French language|French]] nor [[English language|English]].<ref>[http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census06/analysis/language/note.cfm 2006 Census: Portrait of the Canadian Population in 2006, by Language: Note]</ref><ref>[http://faculty.marianopolis.edu/c.belanger/QuebecHistory/events/allos.htm Allophone[s] - Events, Issues and Concepts - Quebec History]</ref>. The term parallels ''[[anglophone]]'' and ''[[francophone]]'', which designate people whose mother tongues are English and French, respectively. Native speakers of [[Indigenous languages of the Americas#United States.2C Canada and Greenland|aboriginal languages]] are generally not treated as allophones.
==Origin of term == The word "'''allophone'''" (from Greek {{lang|grc|ἀλλόφωνος}} ''allóphōnos'' "speaking a foreign tongue")<ref>{{LSJ|a)llo/fwnos|ἀλλόφωνος|ref}}.</ref> is formed from the [[Greek language|Greek]] roots {{lang|grc|ἄλλος}} (''állos''), meaning "other", and {{lang|grc|φωνή}} (''phōnḗ''), meaning "sound" or "voice". The term became popularized during the [[Quiet Revolution]] as [[French Canadian]] society in Quebec sought to integrate immigrants, most of whom had traditionally integrated into the [[English-speaking Quebecers|English-speaking community]]. As integrating immigrants was deemed essential to assure the survival of French-speaking Quebec in light of plummeting birth rates, demographers devised this category to monitor the integration of immigrants into French- and English-speaking communities. Because allophones often adopt English, French or both languages at home or learn one language before another, they can be grouped into English or French communities based on [[home language]] or first official language learned.
== Demographics == === Canada === In 2006, 20% of the [[population]] of [[Canada]] were allophones.<ref>https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/pub/11-402-x/2008/50000/ceb50000_000-fra.htm</ref>
==== Ontario ==== In 2001, 24.2% of the [[population]] of [[Ontario]] were allophones.<ref>https://www.fin.gov.on.ca/en/economy/demographics/census/cenhi4.html</ref>
==== Quebec ==== {| class="wikitable" align="right" |+Quebec allophone population by [[mother tongue]] 2001 <ref>[http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census01/products/standard/themes/RetrieveProductTable.cfm?Temporal=2001&PID=55534&APATH=3&METH=1&PTYPE=55440&THEME=41&FOCUS=0&AID=0&PLACENAME=0&PROVINCE=0&SEARCH=0&GC=99&GK=NA&VID=0&VNAMEE=&VNAMEF=&FL=0&RL=0&FREE=0&GID=431540 97F0007XCB2001002]</ref> |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" !Language !Single !Multiple |- |Total | | |- |1. [[Italian language|Italian]] |124,695 |6,065 |- |2. [[Arabic]] |76,285 |10,245 |- |3. [[Spanish language|Spanish]] |70,100 |4,825 |- |4. [[Greek language|Greek]] |41,980 |1,755 |- |5. [[Haitian Creole]] |34,885 |5,710 |- |6. [[Chinese language|Chinese]] |33,490 |705 |- |7. [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] | 33,360 | 1,455 |- |8. [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] |21,635 |1,125 |- |9. [[German language|German]] |17,690 |995 |- |10. [[Polish language|Polish]] |17,160 |685 |- |11. [[Armenian language|Armenian]] |13,935 |405 |- |12. [[Romanian language|Romanian]] |12,660 |460 |- |13. [[Russian language|Russian]] |12,420 |355 |- |14. [[Tamil language|Tamil]] | 11,095 |860 |- |15. [[Persian language|Persian]] |10,495 |395 |} Allophones constitute an increasing share of the Quebec population and are the main source of population increase in the province, reflecting both increased levels of immigration, declining birthrates among established anglophone and francophone populations, and a shift in immigration from English-speaking countries to Asia and the Americas.<ref>[http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census01/Products/Analytic/companion/lang/provs.cfm#allophones Profile of languages in Canada: Provinces and territories]</ref> In 1971, allophones were 6.6% of the population; by 2001, this had increased to 10.0%. Speakers of Arabic, Spanish and Haitian Creole experienced the greatest growth from 1996 to 2001.<ref name="www12.statcan.ca">[http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census01/Products/Analytic/companion/lang/provs.cfm#frequently Profile of languages in Canada: Provinces and territories]</ref>
Increasing numbers of allophones speak French at home: about 20.4% of allophones in the province reported that they spoke French most often at home in 2001, compared with 16.6% in 1996 and 15.4% in 1991.<ref name="www12.statcan.ca"/> Most allophones live in [[Greater Montreal|Montreal]], Quebec's largest metropolitan area. They tend to migrate out of the province: between 1996 and 2001, over 19,170 migrated to other provinces; 18,810 who migrated to [[Ontario]].<ref>[http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census01/Products/Analytic/companion/lang/tables/migration.cfm Net population gains or losses from interprovincial migration by language group, provinces and territories, 1991-1996 and 1996-2001]</ref>
The majority of [[allophone]] students in [[Quebec]] attend [[francophone]] [[schools]].<ref> https://www.lapresse.ca/news/education/201703/31/01-5084210-les-allophones -frequentent-the-schools-speaking au quebec.php</ref>

Regional vocabulary within [[American English]] varies. Below is a list of [[lexicon|lexical]] differences in vocabulary that are generally associated with a region. A term featured on a list may or may not be found throughout the region concerned, and may or may not be recognized by speakers outside that region. Some terms appear on more than one list.
== Regionalisms == Historically, a number of everyday words and expression used to be characteristic of different dialect areas of the [[United States]], especially the North, the [[Midland American English|Midland]], and the South; many of these terms spread from their area of origin and came to be used throughout the nation. Today many people use these different words for the same object interchangeably, or to distinguish between variations of an object. Such traditional lexical variables include:{{refn|group=notes|Examples in this section are from the ''Dictionary of American Regional English'' (2002), which published lexicology from interviews carried out between 1965 and 1970, except where otherwise noted.<ref name="DARE">Cassidy, Frederic Gomes, and Joan Houston Hall (eds). (2002) ''Dictionary of American Regional English''. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press.</ref> }} * ''[[faucet]]'' (North) and ''spigot'' (South)<ref name="Metcalf">Metcalf, Alan A. (2000) ''How we talk: American regional English today''. New York: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.</ref> * ''[[frying pan]]'' (North and South, but not Midland), ''spider'' (obsolete New England),<ref>Allen, Harold Byron, and Gary N. Underwood (eds). (1971) ''Readings in American Dialectology''. New York: Appleton-Century-Crofts.</ref> and ''skillet'' (Midland and South) * ''[[Rain gutter|gutter]]'' (Northeast, South, and West), ''eaves trough'' (West and Inland North), and ''rainspouting'' (Maryland and Pennsylvania) * ''pit'' (North) and ''seed'' (elsewhere) * ''teeter-totter'' (North; widespread),<ref name="Metcalf"/> ''[[seesaw]]'' (South and Midland; now widespread), and ''dandle'' (Rhode Island) * ''[[firefly]]'' (more Northern and Western) and ''lightning bug'' (widespread) * ''pail'' (North, north Midland) and ''[[bucket]]'' (Midland and South; now widespread) *''sneakers'' (Northeast and fairly widespread) and ''tennis shoes'' (widespread outside the Northeast) *''soda'' (Northeast, Greater Milwaukee, Great St. Louis, California, and Florida), ''pop'' (Inland North, Upper Midwest, and Northwest), ''coke'' (South), and ''tonic'' (Eastern New England possibility) * ''you guys'' (widespread), ''y'all'' (Southern and South Midland), ''you'uns'' and '' yins'' (Western Pennsylvania), and ''yous'' or ''youse'' (New York City, Philadelphia, New Jersey, and Northeastern Pennsylvania)<ref name="Vaux"/>
However many differences still hold and mark boundaries between different dialect areas, as shown below. From 2000-2005, for instance, ''The Dialect Survey'' queried North American English speakers' usage of a variety of linguistic items, including vocabulary items that vary by region.<ref name="Vaux">Vaux, Bert, Scott A. Golder, Rebecca Starr, and Britt Bolen. (2000-2005) ''[http://www4.uwm.edu//FLL/linguistics/dialect/index.html The Dialect Survey]''. Survey and maps.</ref> These include: * generic term for a sweetened carbonated beverage * drink made with milk and ice cream * long sandwich that contains cold cuts, lettuce, and so on * rubber-soled shoes worn in gym class, for athletic activities, etc.
Below are lists outlining regional vocabularies in the main dialect areas of the United States.
== North == {{See also|Inland Northern American English|North Central American English}} * ''braht'' or ''brat'' - [[bratwurst]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''breezeway'' (widespread) ("skyway" in Minnesota) - a hallway connecting two buildings<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[bubbler]]'' (esp. New England, Wisconsin and the Mississippi and Ohio river valleys) - a water fountain<ref name="DARE"/> * ''clout'' (originally Chicago, now widespread) - political or social influence<ref name="DARE"/> * [[Davenport (sofa)|''davenport'']] (widespread) - a sofa, or couch<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[euchre]]'' (throughout the North) - card game similar to spades<ref name="DARE"/> * ''fridge'' (throughout North and West) - [[refrigerator]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[hotdish]]'' (esp. Minnesota) - a simple entree cooked in a single dish, related to [[casserole]]<ref>Mohr, Howard. (1987) ''How to Talk Minnesotan: A Visitor's Guide''. New York: Penguin.</ref> * ''[[Pączki|paczki]]'' (in Polish settlement areas, esp. Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin) - a jelly doughnut<ref name="DARE"/> * ''pop'' (widespread in North-Central and West) - a soft drink, carbonated soda<ref name="DARE"/> * ''soda'' (all the Northeast and parts of Wisconsin) - soft drink<ref name="PopSoda"/> * ''Yooper'' (Michigan) - people who reside in the [[Upper Peninsula of Michigan]]<ref>Binder, David. (14 September 1995). "Upper Peninsula Journal: Yes, They're Yoopers, and Proud of it." New York Times, section A, page 16.</ref>
=== Northeast === {{See also|Northern American English#Northeastern American English}} * ''brook'' - creek. Mainly New England, now widespread but especially common in the Northeast<ref name="DARE"/> * ''cellar'' - alternate term for basement<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www3.uwm.edu/Dept/FLL/linguistics/dialect/staticmaps/q_117.html |title=Dialect Survey-Level of a building that is partly or entirely underground |publisher=[[University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee]] |accessdate=2008-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906190640/http://www3.uwm.edu/Dept/FLL/linguistics/dialect/staticmaps/q_117.html |archivedate=2008-09-06 |df= }}</ref> * ''sneaker'' - although found throughout the U.S., appears to be concentrated in the Northeast. Elsewhere (except for parts of Florida) ''tennis shoe'' is more common.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www3.uwm.edu/Dept/FLL/linguistics/dialect/staticmaps/q_73.html |title=Dialect Survey - General term for rubber-soled shoes worn for athletic activities, etc. |publisher=[[University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee]] |accessdate=2008-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829115150/http://www3.uwm.edu/Dept/FLL/linguistics/dialect/staticmaps/q_73.html |archivedate=2008-08-29 |df= }}</ref> * ''soda'' - a soft drink<ref name="PopSoda">Campbell, Matthew T. (2003) [http://popvssoda.com:2998/countystats/total-county.html ''Generic names for soft drinks by county''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080811135425/http://popvssoda.com:2998/countystats/total-county.html |date=2008-08-11 }}. Map.</ref> * ''[[Mischief Night]]'' (or, rarely, ''Cabbage Night'') - night when, by custom, preteens and teenagers play pranks; usually, the night before [[Halloween]]<ref name="DARE"/>
==== New England ==== * ''grinder'' - [[submarine sandwich]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''packie'' (''package store'') - a liquor store<ref name="DARE"/> * ''rotary'' - [[traffic circle]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''tag sale'' - garage sale<ref name="DARE"/> * ''wicked'' (all of Massachusetts) - very; an intensifier and adverb, as in ''wicked cold'' meaning ''very cold''<ref name="Metcalf" />
==== Eastern New England ==== {{see also|Boston accent}} * ''bulkhead'' - cellar hatchway<ref name="DARE"/> * ''cabinet'' (Rhode Island) - milk shake<ref name="DARE"/> * ''frappe'' - [[milkshake]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''hosey'' - (esp. parts of Massachusetts & Maine) to stake a claim or choose sides, to claim ownership of something (sometimes, the front seat of a car)<ref name="DARE"/> * ''intervale'' - bottomland; mostly historical<ref name="DARE"/> * ''jimmies'' - [[sprinkles]] (ice cream topping)<ref name="DARE"/> see also [[#The Mid-Atlantic|Mid-Atlantic, below]] * ''[[johnnycake]]'' (also ''Rhode Island jonnycake'') – a type of cornmeal bread<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[leaf peeper]]'' - a tourist who has come to see the area's vibrant autumn foliage<ref name="DARE"/> * ''necessary'' - outhouse, privy<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[quahog]]'' - pronounced "koe-hog," it properly refers to a specific species of clam but is also applied to any clam<ref name="DARE"/> * ''tonic'' (eastern Massachusetts) - soft drink<ref name="DARE"/>
==== Northern New England ==== * ''ayuh'' - "yes" or affirmative<ref name="DARE"/> * ''creemee'' - (Vermont) soft serve ice cream <ref>{{cite book|last=Bartlett|first=Ray|author2=Gregor Clark |author3=Dan Eldridge |author4=Brandon Presser |title=Lonely Planet New England Trips|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vt1Z-ddh7KcC&pg=PA265|accessdate=4 September 2013|year=2010|publisher=Lonely Planet|isbn=978-1-74220-391-1}}</ref> * ''dooryard'' - area around the main entry door of a house, specifically a farmhouse. Typically including the [[driveway]] and parking area proximal to the house<ref name="DARE"/> * ''Italian'' (''sandwich'') - (Maine) [[submarine sandwich]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''logan'' (also ''pokelogan'') - a shallow, swampy lake or pond (from [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]])<ref name="DARE"/> * ''muckle'' - to grasp, hold-fast, or tear into<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[mud season]]'' - early spring <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yankeemagazine.com/article/features/mud-season |title=Mud season: New England's fifth season |publisher=Yankee |last=Collins |first=Jim |date=March 2008 |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref><ref name="ZielinskiKeim2005">{{cite book|last1=Zielinski|first1=Gregory A.|last2=Keim|first2=Barry D.|title=New England Weather, New England Climate|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k-ASosvSGW8C&pg=PA91|accessdate=4 September 2013|year=2005|publisher=UPNE|isbn=978-1-58465-520-6}}</ref>
== Mid-Atlantic ==
{{see also|Philadelphia accent|Baltimore accent|Pittsburgh English|Central Pennsylvania dialect|Northeast Pennsylvania English|Pennsylvania Dutch English}} * ''breezeway'' - the space between two groups of rowhouses in the middle of a city block<ref name="DARE"/> * ''down the shore'' - shore areas and beaches of Southern New Jersey<ref name="Philly" /> * ''[[hoagie]]'' - [[submarine sandwich]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''jawn'' - pronoun used for any person, place, or thing<ref name="Philly">{{cite web| url=http://blog.coldwellbanker.com/philly-slang-philadelphia-sayings-you-dont-hear-anywhere-else/ | work=Caldwell Banker | title=Philly Slang: Philadelphia Sayings You Don’t Hear Anywhere Else|last=Freeman|first=Amy | date=March 4, 2015 | accessdate=February 12, 2017}}{{Better source|reason=Author appears to be a realtor (estate agent) who is expert on Philadelphia but not on language.|date=February 2017}}</ref> * ''jimmies'' - sprinkles (ice cream topping)<ref name="Jimmies">{{cite web|url=https://icecreamjournal.turkeyhill.com/index.php/2008/07/03/whats-the-difference-between-sprinkles-and-jimmies/|title=WHAT’S THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN SPRINKLES AND JIMMIES?|accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> see also [[#Eastern New England|New England, above]] * ''parlor'' - [[living room]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''pavement'' - [[sidewalk]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[shoobie]]'' - A visitor to the beach (typically the [[South Jersey]] shore) for the day (as contrasted with an overnight visitor)<ref name="DARE"/> * ''water ice'' - [[Italian ice]]<ref name="Philly" /> * ''yo!'' - Hello; also used to grab someone's attention<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elliottsamazing.com/phltalk.html |title=How they Talk in Philadelphia|work=elliotsamazing.com|accessdate=2017-02-13}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=Personal blog|date=February 2017}} * ''youze'' - plural form of "you people"<ref name="youze">{{cite web|title=Philly Slang|last=Bykofsky|first=Stu|date=July 16, 2006|url=http://phillytalk.com/funny-stuff/philly/philly-slang_3.html |work=PhillyTalk.com|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080323161534/http://phillytalk.com/funny-stuff/philly/philly-slang_3.html |archive-date=March 23, 2008 }}</ref>
=== Greater New York City ===
{{See also|New York dialect}} * ''bodega'' - small corner grocery store<ref name="DARE"/> * ''catty corner'' - on an angle to a corner<ref name="DARE"/> * ''dungarees'' (older) - [[jeans]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[egg cream]]'' - a mixture of cold milk, flavored syrup, and seltzer<ref name="DARE"/> * ''have a catch'' - play catch<ref name="DARE"/> * ''hero'' - submarine sandwich<ref name="DARE"/> * ''kill'' - a small river or strait, in the name of specific watercourses; e.g. [[Beaver Kill]], [[Fresh Kills]], [[Kill Van Kull]], [[Arthur Kill]] (from Dutch)<ref name="DARE"/> * ''on line'' - waiting or standing in a line<ref name="Metcalf"/> * ''potsy'' - [[hopscotch]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[punchball]]'' - a baseball-like game suitable for smaller areas, in which a fist substitutes for the bat and a "spaldeen" is the ball<ref name="DARE"/> * ''scallion'' - spring onion<ref name="DARE"/> * [[Urban stoop|''stoop'']] - a small porch or steps in front of a building, originally from Dutch<ref name="STOOP">{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/stoop |title=Stoop | Define Stoop at Dictionary.com |publisher=Dictionary.reference.com |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
== Midland == {{See also|Midland American English}} * ''barn-burner'' (now widespread) - an exciting, often high-scoring game, esp. a basketball game<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[hoosier]]'' (esp. Indiana) - someone from [[Indiana]]; (outside of Indiana, esp. in the St. Louis, Missouri area) a person from a rural area, comparable to ''[[redneck]]''<ref name="Metcalf"/> * ''mango'' - green [[bell pepper]], sometimes also various [[chili pepper]]s<ref name="DARE"/> * ''outer road'' - a [[frontage road]] or other service road<ref name="DARE"/> A soft drink is generally known in the American Midland as ''pop'', except for being ''soda'' around [[Greater St. Louis]] in Missouri and Illinois, and ''coke'' in central Indiana and central and western Oklahoma<ref name="PopSoda"/>
== South == {{see also|Southern American English}} * ''alligator pear'' - [[avocado]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''banquette'' (southern Louisiana) - [[sidewalk]], foot-path<ref name="DARE"/> * ''billfold'' (widespread, but infrequent Northeast, Pacific Northwest) - a man's wallet<ref name="DARE"/> * ''cap'' (also Midlands) - sir (prob. from "captain")<ref name="DARE"/> * ''chill bumps'' (also Midlands) - goose bumps<ref name="DARE"/> * ''chuck'' - toss or throw an object<ref name="Metcalf"/> (Now somewhat widespread) * ''coke'' - any brand of soft drink<ref name="PopSoda"/> * ''commode'' (also Midlands) - bathroom; restroom; particularly the [[flush toilet|toilet]] itself<ref name="DARE"/> * ''crocus sack'' (Atlantic), ''croker sack'' (Gulf) - burlap bag<ref name="DARE"/> * ''cut on/off'' - to turn on/off<ref name="DARE"/> * ''directly'' - in a minute; soon; presently<ref name="DARE"/> * ''dirty rice'' (esp. Louisiana) - Cajun rice dish consisting of rice, spices, and meat<ref name="DARE"/> * ''fais-dodo'' (southern Louisiana) - a party<ref name="DARE"/> * ''fix'' - to get ready, to be on the verge of doing, e.g. "I'm fixing to go"; (widespread but esp. South) to prepare food<ref name="DARE"/> * ''house shoes'' - bedroom slippers<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[lagniappe]]'' (Gulf, esp. Louisiana) - a little bit of something extra<ref name="DARE"/> * ''locker'' (esp. Louisiana) - [[closet]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''make'' (age) (Gulf, esp. Louisiana) - have a birthday; "He's making 16 tomorrow."<ref name="DARE"/> * ''neutral ground'' (Louisiana, Mississippi) - [[Central reservation|median strip]]<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[po' boy]]'' (scattered, but esp. South) - a long sandwich, typically made with fried oysters, clams, or shrimp<ref name="DARE"/> * ''put up'' - put away, put back in its place<ref name="DARE"/> * ''yankee'' - northerner; also ''damn yankee'', ''damned yankee''<ref name="DARE"/> * ''yonder'' (esp. rural) - over there, or a long distance away; also ''over yonder''<ref>Wolfram, Walt, and Natalie Schilling-Estes. (2006) ''American English: dialects and variation'' second edition. New York: Wiley-Blackwell.</ref>
== West == {{See also|California English|New Mexican English}}
* ''barrow pit'' (esp. Rocky Mountains) – a ditch to conduct water off a surface road<ref name="DARE"/> * ''davenport'' (widespread) - couch or sofa<ref name="DARE"/> * ''[[hella]]'' (esp. Bay Area) - "very" or "a lot of"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ww2.kqed.org/news/2015/08/20/the-origins-of-hella |title=The Origins of Hella |publisher=KQED |last=Eghan |first=Adizah |date=August 2015|accessdate=2015-11-18}}</ref> * ''pop'' (widespread in West and North) - carbonated beverages; ''soda'' predominates in California, Arizona, southern Nevada,<ref name="PopSoda"/> while ''coke'' is used in parts of [[New Mexico]] and Tuscon, Arizona<ref>{{cite book |last=Labov |first=William |last2=Ash |first2=Sharon |last3=Boberg |first3=Charles |date=2006 |title=The Atlas of North American English |location=Berlin |publisher=Mouton-de Gruyter |page=289 |isbn=3-11-016746-8}}</ref> * ''snowmachine'' (Alaska) – a motor vehicle for travel over snow. Outside Alaska known as a ''[[snowmobile]]''<ref name="OED2">''Oxford English Dictionary'' Second Edition. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1989.</ref>
=== Pacific Northwest === {{see also|Pacific Northwest English}}
* ''skid road'' or ''[[skid row]]'' - a path made of logs or timbers along which logs are pulled; (widespread) a run-down, impoverished urban area<ref name="DARE"/><ref name="OED2"/>

{{italic title}} The '''''Anonymi Chronicon Austriacum''''' (Anonymous Austrian chronicle) is an anonymous [[Middle Latin]] chronicle that covers the years 973–1327.<ref name=Molinier>[[Auguste Molinier]], [http://www.persee.fr/doc/shf_0000-0000_1903_num_3_1_942_t1_0207_0000_2 "2903. Chronicon Austriacum (973–1327), publiée dans A. Rauch, ''Rerum Austriacarum scriptores'', II, 209–312,"] ''Collections numériques de la Sorbonne'', '''3''' (1903), p. 207.</ref> It was first published in 1793 by Adrian Rauch alongside the ''[[Annales Zwetlenses]]'', both from a paper manuscript he found in the [[Austrian National Library|Bibliotheca Palatina Vindobonensis (Palatine Library of Vienna)]]<!--, numbered MS rec. 1548 and compiled by [[Ladislaus Sunthaym]]-->.<ref name=Rauch>Cf. Rauch, 209ff.</ref>
It is an important source for the late 13th and early 14th century in [[Austria]]. It also contains pertinent information about [[France in the Middle Ages|France]] during the reigns of the German kings [[Adolf of Germany|Adolf]] (1292–98) and [[Albert I of Germany|Albert I]] (1298–1308).<ref name=Molinier/> It is the only source for the [[Mongol raid in the Latin Empire]] in 1242. Its account of this raid was copied into the ''[[Chronicon Leobiense]]'' and the ''[[Continuatio Sancrucensis]]''.<ref>István Vásáry, ''Cumans and Tatars: Oriental Military in the Pre-Ottoman Balkans, 1185–1365'' (Cambridge University Press, 2005), p. 70.</ref>
==Editions== *[https://books.google.ca/books?id=9Tk_AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA209 "Anonymi Chronicon Austriacum"], in Adrian Rauch (ed.), ''Rerum Austriacarum Scriptores'', vol. 2 (Vienna, 1793), pp. 209–312. *"Chronicon Austriacum anonymi", in Ferenc Albin Gombos (ed.), ''Catalogus fontium historiae Hungaricae aevo ducum et regum ex stirpe Arpad descendentium ab anno Christi dccc usque ad annum mccci'', vol. 1 (Budapest, 1937), pp. 504–18.

'''Anonymous Bulgarian Chronicle''' is a term used for several [[Anonymity|anonymous]] [[chronicle]]s written in [[Bulgaria]] during the [[Middle Ages]].
==11th/12th centuries== The term is used when referring to an [[apocryphal]] [[Apocalyptic literature|apocalyptic]] chronicle written in Bulgaria in the late eleventh or early twelfth century.<ref name=ag>Antoanetta Granberg, {{cite web|url= http://www.helsinki.fi/slavicahelsingiensia/preview/sh35/pdf/4.pdf|title=Transferred in Translation. Making a State in Early Medieval Bulgarian Genealogies}}[http://www.helsinki.fi/slavicahelsingiensia/preview/sh35/pdf/4.pdf] {{small|(252 KB)}}, SLAVICA HELSINGIENSIA 35, 2008</ref><ref name="Borislavov2004">{{cite book|author=Yassen Borislavov|title=Bulgarian wine book: history, culture, cellars, wines|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hUI7Z_RdBawC&pg=PA74|accessdate=10 November 2011|date=1 January 2004|publisher=TRUD Publishers|isbn=978-954-528-478-6|page=74}}</ref> This work is also known as the "apocryphal Bulgarian chronicle".<ref>[http://archive.ifla.org/VII/s13/pubs/AnonymousClassics2004.pdf Anonymous classics: a list of uniform headings for European literatures]. Second edition revised by the Working group set up by the IFLA Standing Committee of the Section on Cataloguing</ref>
Such chronicles were relatively common in Bulgaria and [[Byzantium]] of that period, and their defining characteristic was that they purported to come from a [[prophet]], delivering God's message and announcing that the Apocalypse is near.<ref name=ag/>
==15th century== Several sources refer to an early 15th-century work of that name.<ref name="KhristovKosev1963">{{cite book|author1=Khristo Angelov Khristov|author2=Dimitǔr Konstantinov Kosev|title=A short history of Bulgaria|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ruIbAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=10 November 2011|year=1963|publisher=Foreign Languages Press|page=128}}</ref><ref name="Historyistorii︠a︡1987">{{cite book|author1=United Center for Research and Training in History|author2=Edinen t︠s︡entŭr za nauka i podgotovka na kadri po istorii︠a︡|title=Revue bulgare d'histoire|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1eFBAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=10 November 2011|year=1987|publisher=Pub. House of the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences|page=93}}</ref><ref name="India)1991">{{cite book|author=Research Programme for Macedonian Studies (New Delhi, India)|title=Macedonian studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SHJpAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=10 November 2011|year=1991|publisher=Research Programme for Macedonian Studies|page=60}}</ref><ref name="ParryYapp1975">{{cite book|author1=Vernon J. Parry|author2=Malcolm Yapp|author2-link=Malcolm Yapp|title=War, technology and society in the Middle East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ip1tAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=10 November 2011|year=1975|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=175}}</ref>
According to Khristov this work is focused on the [[Ottoman invasion of the Balkans]].<ref name="KhristovKosev1963"/> Imber, however, is more critical of its coverage of that time period. According to him that work provides a narrative from 1296 to the death of Sultan [[Bayezid I]] in 1403 and only has a few brief and rather inaccurate entries focusing on the Ottoman civil war.<ref name="Imber1990">{{cite book|author=Colin Imber|title=The Ottoman Empire, 1300-1481|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lIppAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=10 November 2011|year=1990|publisher=Isis Press|isbn=978-975-428-015-9|page=7}}</ref> This work has been identified it as one of the two important Slavonic literary histories for that time and place.<ref name="Imber1990"/> Due to the relatively undescriptive name, it is possible that Khristov and Imber discuss two different works.
Göyünç, Kreiser and Neumann discuss the work of that name noting that it reaches the year 1417 and that has been "identified as an Old-Bulgarian translation of the Byzantine chronicle of [[John Chrostasmenos]] ([[John Chrysostom]]?)."<ref name="GöyünçKreiser1997">{{cite book|author1=Nejat Göyünç|author2=Klaus Kreiser|author3=Christoph K. Neumann|title=Das osmanische Reich in seinen Archivalien und Chroniken: Nejat Göyünç zu Ehren|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rVVtAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=10 November 2011|year=1997|publisher=In Kommission bei Franz Steiner Verlag, Stuttgart|isbn=978-3-515-07034-8|page=32}}</ref> Another work uses this term to refer to a chronicle covering years 1296-1413.<ref name="StudiesAssociation2003">{{cite book|author1=University of Melbourne. Dept. of Russian and Language Studies|author2=Australian and New Zealand Slavists' Association|author3=Australasian Association for Study of the Socialist Countries|title=Australian Slavonic and East European studies: journal of the Australian and New Zealand Slavists' Association and of the Australasian Association for Study of the Socialist Countries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jw5KAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=10 November 2011|date=1 January 2003|publisher=Dept. of Russian and Language Studies, University of Melbourne|page=7}}</ref> For the reasons mentioned above, it is not certain whether the scholars in question are discussing a single chronicle, ending in the early 15th century, or several different ones.

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Arts in ''Second Life''}} '''Arts in ''Second Life''''' is an artistic area of a 3D social network (called ''[[Second Life]]'') that has served, since 2003, as a platform for various artistic pursuits and exhibitions. SL Photography is one of the most popular forms of artistic expression with images known as "snapshots" produced while travelling through ''Second Life''{{'}}s virtual environment. Many of these snapshots are displayed through various mediums that include Art Galleries, [[Machinima]] websites and Second Life Magazines. == Art exhibits == Second Life has created an environment where artists can display their works to an audience across the world. This has created an entire artistic culture where many residents display art in the museums, galleries and homes they can buy or build using Second Life's powerful tools. Gallery openings even allow art patrons to "meet" and socialize with exhibiting artists and has even led to many real life sales. Numerous art gallery simulations (called "sims") abound in Second Life. Among the more popular galleries are the Sisse Singhs Art Gallery, the Windlight art Gallery and the Horus Art Gallery. Among the most notable of these was the art gallery sim Cetus Gallery District, the world's first virtual online urban arts district. Cetus was modeled on real world analogs such as New York's Chelsea gallery district as a mixed-use arts community of virtual galleries, offices, loft apartments, and coffee houses. Its many tenant-run businesses featured weekly live music performances, gallery openings, and literary events such as the virtual book launch for "Coming of Age in Second Life: An Anthropologist Explores the Virtually Human," by Tom Boellstorf (Princeton University Press; 2008). Cetus was chosen Best Cultural Site in Second Life in 2007, and its creator avatar Xander Ruttan (real world arts professional Aaron Collins of California), was among the most influential art world avatars in SL. Cetus resulted in many ongoing collaborative efforts among the SL community of artists, designers, writers, and virtual builders from across the real and virtual worlds. (Cetus was later bought by virtual artist DB Bailey and converted into a personal art project). The modeling tools from ''Second Life'' allow the artists also to create new forms of art that in many ways are not possible in real life due to physical constraints or high associated costs. The virtual arts are visible in over 2050 "museums" (according to SL's own search engine).{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/sundayarts/thursdays/ |title=Thursdays |accessdate = 2007-08-15}} In 2008 Haydn Shaughnessy, [[real life]] gallerist, along with his wife Roos Demol hired a [[real life]] architect, [[New York City|New York]] based, Benn Dunkley to design a gallery in Second Life. Dunkleys goal was to design an interactive gallery with art in mind in a virtual world. "Ten Cubed" is a radical departure in art exhibition, a futuristically designed gallery showcasing art in a unique setting. On January 31, 2008, "Ten Cubed" was launched. For its [[inaugural]] exhibition, ''Crossing the Void II'', owner and curator Shaughnessy selected five artists working in and with modern technologies. These artists included Chris Ashley based in [[Oakland, California]], [[Jon Coffelt]] based in [[New York, New York]], Claire Keating based in [[Cork (city)|Cork, Ireland]], Scott Kildall based in [[San Francisco, California]] and [[Nathaniel Stern]] originally based in [[New York, New York]] now in [[Dublin, Ireland]].[http://www.depoconsulting.com/blog/?p=16 Inaugural artists in ''Crossing the Void II''for "Ten Cubed," curated by Haydn Shaughnessy] [[Real life]] as well as Second Life editions are available from the gallery. The virtual creations from the [[metaverse]] are disclosed in real life by initiatives such as Fabjectory (statuettes){{cite web |url=http://www.fabjectory.com/secondlife/ |title=Fabjectory |accessdate = 2007-05-06}} and Secondlife-Art.com (oil paintings).{{cite web| url= http://www.secondlife-art.com/| title= Secondlife-Art.com: real life paintings from Second Life| accessdate= 2007-03-02| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070213084658/http://www.secondlife-art.com/#| archivedate= 2007-02-13| deadurl= yes| df= }} In April 2007 the huge gallery called crossworlds gallery opened its doors in Secondlife; therefore,{{cite web|url=http://www.gallery.de |title=crossworlds gallery at gallery.de |date=2007-04-15 |accessdate=2011-11-18}} the aim was to create an open space for art in virtual worlds. Also in 2007, artists Adam Nash, Christopher Dodds and [[Justin Clemens]] won a A$20,000 Second Life Artists in Residence grant{{cite web|url=http://www.australiacouncil.gov.au/the_arts/features/australias_first_second_life_arts_residency |title=Australia's first Second Life arts residency - Australia Council for the Arts |publisher=Australiacouncil.gov.au |accessdate=2010-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100311224257/http://www.australiacouncil.gov.au/the_arts/features/australias_first_second_life_arts_residency |archivedate=2010-03-11 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/technology/theyre-virtually-famous/2008/04/10/1207856776808.html?s_cid=rss_technology |title=They're virtually famous - Technology |publisher=theage.com.au |date=2009-06-15 |accessdate=2010-02-19}}{{cite web|author=Mahesh Sharma |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/arts/old-funds-for-new-worlds/story-e6frg8n6-1111116470411 |title=Old funds for new worlds |publisher=The Australian |date=2008-05-29 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} from the [[Australia Council for the Arts]]. Their ''Babelswarm'' installation was launched in Second Life and The Lismore Regional Gallery in [[NSW]], Australia on April 11, 2008 by Australia Council Chairman [[James Strong (Australian businessman)|James Strong]].{{cite web |url=http://www.babelswarm.com/review.html |title=Babelswarm |publisher=Babelswarm |date=2008-04-14 |accessdate=2010-02-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707203226/http://www.babelswarm.com/review.html# |archive-date=2011-07-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In 2008, the French Artist Fred Forest{{cite web|url=http://www.webnetmuseum.org/html/en/expo-retr-fredforest/actions/70_a_en.htm#text |title=Web Net Museum-Fred forest-Retrospective-Art sociologique-Esthetique de la communication-Interrogation-Oeuvres Actions-Les robinets planetaires |publisher=Webnetmuseum.org |accessdate=2010-02-19}} had entered the virtual world of Second Life to show his art project for the first time in his country. He inaugurated his "Experimental Center of the Territory of M2" ("Centre expérimental du terrioire du M2"), where he invited politicians to discuss about sustainable development and digital identity card ( Capucine.net). In another art project, he discussed about art institutions in France in his action called "l'art de la corrida". == Live music == Live music performances in ''Second Life'' takes place in three distinctly different ways; * With in-world voice chat, where the user dons a headset and microphone then enables a Second Life browse to "broadcast" his voice to other users, much like a telephone conference call. * With streaming, where vocal and instrumental music by ''Second Life'' residents can be provided with the aid of Internet broadcast software, such as Shoutcast. This is input, via microphones, instruments or other audio sources, into computer audio interfaces and streamed live to audio servers. Similar to webcast radio, the audio stream from the live performance can be received in ''Second Life'' for the enjoyment of other Residents on their computer speakers. This started with performances by Astrin Few in May 2004 and began to gain popularity mid-2005. For example, the UK band Passenger performed on the Menorca Island in mid-2006. Another UK band, [[Redzone]], toured in ''Second Life'' in February 2007. * With inworld samples, where sounds samples are uploaded and an inworld user interface – instruments – is made to trigger those. Unlike streaming, performing with inworld samples make use of the ''Second Life'' environment and creates a three-dimensional sound experience to the audience. The [[Avatar Orchestra Metaverse]] is the most prolific representative with this approach. Linden Lab added an Event Category "Live Music" in March 2006 to accommodate the increasing number of scheduled events. By the beginning of 2008, scheduled live music performance events in ''Second Life'' spanned every musical genre, and included hundreds of live musicians and DJs who perform on a regular basis. A typical day in ''Second Life'' will feature dozens of live music performances. In 2008 the UK act [[Redzone]] announced they would release their new live album only via Second Life.{{cite web|url=http://www.side-line.com/news_comments.php?id=30314_0_2_1_C |title=New Redzone live album only available in Second Life |publisher=Side-line.com |accessdate=2010-02-19}} [[Redzone]] also began choreographing and synchronising their performances via MIDI in October 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.redzone.tv/redzone/press/news/2008.htm |title=MIDI-to-SecondLife Synchronisation Perfected |publisher=Redzone.tv |accessdate=2010-02-19}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Many amateur performers start their music careers in Second Life by performing at virtual karaoke bars{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.ireport.com/docs/DOC-18485 |title=Of Avatars and Microphones |publisher=Ireport.com |date=2008-05-03 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} or Open Mic, then progress to performing for "pay", or Linden dollars, in-world. == Filming with machinima == [[File:Machinima sample reindeer full size.ogg|thumb|right|Film made in Second Life using [[machinima]].]] ''Second Life'' is popular for filming with [[machinima]]. Virtual worlds can contain all aspects of real world filming techniques as well as many more not possible in the real world. It is far easier to create 3D objects in ''Second Life'' and film them than create them from 'scratch' using traditional [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]] software. There are many machinima and performing arts groups that are active in ''Second Life'' and which participate in creative events such as the annual 48 Hour Film Project. There are also several machinima groups that actively promote the works of Second Life artists such as Machinima Mondays, Rezzed TV, MAGE Magazine and the Machinima Artist's guild.{{cite web |url=http://www.48hourfilm.com/en/machinima/|title=The 48 Hour Film Project: Machinima|author=The 48 Hour Film Project|date=January 1, 2014|accessdate=February 3, 2015}} == Theater == Live theater is presented in ''Second Life''. The [[SL Shakespeare Company]]{{cite web|url=http://slshakespeare.com/ |title=The SL Shakespeare Company: Homepage |publisher=Slshakespeare.com |accessdate=2008-10-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081031212730/http://slshakespeare.com/| archivedate= 31 October 2008 | deadurl= no}} performed an act from ''Hamlet'' live in February 2008. In 2009, the company produced scenes from ''[[Twelfth Night]]''. In 2007 Johannes von Matuschka and Daniel Michelis developed Wunderland, an interactive SL theatre play at Schaubühne am Lehniner Platz in Berlin, Germany.{{cite web|url=http://slwunderland.wordpress.com |title=Wunderland |publisher=Slwunderland.wordpress.com |accessdate=2008-10-27}} In 2007, HBO hosted a comedy festival in ''Second Life,''{{cite web |url=http://www.3pointd.com/20070228/hbo-comedy-festival-coming-to-second-life/ |title=HBO Comedy Festival Coming to Second Life |publisher=3pointd.com |date=2007-02-28 |accessdate=2010-02-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707064015/http://www.3pointd.com/20070228/hbo-comedy-festival-coming-to-second-life/# |archive-date=2011-07-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} using live streaming audio. In March 2009, SL residents staged a two-day Virtually Funny Comedy Festival to "help build awareness for Comic Relief, Red Nose Day 2009 and of course, comedy in Second Life."{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.ireport.com/docs/DOC-228896 |title=Virtual Comedians Pick a Red Nose in Second Life |publisher=iReport.com |date=2009-03-13 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} In December 2008, The Learning Experience,{{cite web|url=http://tleinsl.com/index.htm |title=The Learning Experience Web site |publisher=Tleinsl.com |accessdate=2010-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100417125317/http://www.tleinsl.com/index.htm |archivedate=2010-04-17 |df= }} a not-for-profit [[virtual education]] campus in Second Life, staged its first live theater events with the production of two short plays,{{cite web|url=http://tleinsl.blogspot.com/2008/12/it-was-night-of-many-firsts.html |title=It Was a Night of Many Firsts |publisher=Tleinsl.blogspot.com |date=2008-12-05 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} ''A Matter of Husbands'' by [[Ferenc Molnár]] and ''Porcelain and Pink'' by [[F. Scott Fitzgerald]]. In 2009, the TLE theater company began producing full-length plays in Second Life, starting with ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' by [[Oscar Wilde]] in February,{{cite web|url=http://tleinsl.blogspot.com/2009/02/first-full-length-play-staged-by-tle-in.html |title=First Full-length Play Staged by TLE in Virtual World Is a Real Success! |publisher=Tleinsl.blogspot.com |date=2009-02-22 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} and followed by ''Candida'' by [[George Bernard Shaw]] in April.{{cite web|url=http://tleinsl.blogspot.com/2009/04/sexes-battle-it-out-in-candida-on-tle.html |title=The Sexes Battle It Out in Candida on the TLE Stage in Second Life |publisher=Tleinsl.blogspot.com |date=2009-04-03 |accessdate=2010-02-19}}{{cite web|url=http://tleinsl.blogspot.com/2009/04/dont-miss-virtually-real-performance-of.html |title=Don't Miss 'Virtually Real' Performance of Candida at TLE in Second Life |publisher=Tleinsl.blogspot.com |date=2009-04-12 |accessdate=2010-02-19}} In 2008 The [[Avatar Repertory Theater]] company was set up. This is another Theatre company that works within SL."Theatre in the Virtual World- A look at Avatar Repertory Theater" ''Breaking Character''25 September 2012 last accessed 2012-10-24 In 2009 the Department of Drama at the University of Calgary mounted four short productions in the New Media Consortium theater as part of a class in performance in non-traditional spaces. These plays were (a) ''Guppies'' (by Clem Martini) in March (b) [http://www.10-minute-plays.com/comedies/the_chocolate_affair.html The Chocolate Affair] (by Stephanie Alison Walker); (c) [http://www.10-minute-plays.com/comedies/kingdom_of_the_spider.html Kingdom of the Spider] (by Nick Zagone); (d) [http://www.freedrama.net/one.html The Boy Who Cried Genie] (by D. M. Bocaz-Larson).Jim Parker and Clem Martini. Producing Live Theatre in Virtual Spaces: Real Performances/Alternative Landscape , Arts in Society Conference 2010, Sydney Australia, 22–25 July.Jim Parker and Clem Martini, Puppetry of the Pixel: Producing Live Theatre in Virtual Spaces, 3rd IEEE International Workshop on Digital Entertainment, Networked Virtual Environments, and Creative Technology - CCNC 2011: 3rd IEEE International Workshop on Digital Entertainment, Networked Virtual Environments, and Creative Technology, Las Vegas, NV. Jan 9-11, 2011. In 2011/12, an all-[[Furry fandom|furry]] performing arts troupe, Ravenswood Theatricals, was launched at their own venue with successful, non-commercial virtual renditions of [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]]'s ''[[The Wizard of Oz (2011 musical)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' and ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'', the latter of which was received with glowing reviews.Forepawz Golem, "[http://www.slarf.org/phantom-of-the-opera/ The Phantom of the Opera — Show Review]," ''Second Life Avatar Review Files'', March 31, 2012."[http://renoobed.wordpress.com/2011/11/19/the-ravenswood-theatre-company-presents-phantom-of-the-opera/ The Ravenswood Theatre Company Presents Phantom of the Opera]," ''Renoobed'', Nov. 19, 2011. A number of further productions of established real-life pieces such as ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'', ''[[Tanz der Vampire]]'', ''[[Sunset Boulevard (musical)|Sunset Boulevard]]'', and ''[[Into the Woods]]'' are reportedly planned, as well as a gala presentation of various musical numbers from upcoming productions. ==Virtual dance== [[Virtual dance]] has been elevated in Second Life. Ballet Pixelle® (formerly Second Life Ballet) was the first performing [[ballet company]] in Second Life (2006). Ballet Pixelle®, with founder and artistic director Inarra Saarinen, produces all original animations, choreography, and music composed specifically for each ballet. All dance is done as art, not automation, with the dancers actually dancing with each other and the music—there is no artificial synchronization involved.{{Cite web |url=http://wwwballetpixelle.org/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2018-11-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130727204428/http://wwwballetpixelle.org/# |archive-date=2013-07-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }} La Performance.http://www.la-performance.org/ started in May 2008 with live dance shows. Two shows are produced in a year, in March/April/May 2010 modern ballet show 'BACK TO BLACK'http://www.la-performance.org/show/174/back-to-black with music by [[Queen (band)]], [[Francisco de la Torre (composer)|Francisco de la Torre]], [[Metallica]], [[Amy Winehouse]], [[Paula Cole]], [[Richard Wagner]], [[Louis Armstrong]], [[Suzi Quatro]]. October/November/December 2010: 'POLYAMOUR': this modern ballet show was danced live to a live concert by REIS and Aldo Brizzi (vocals and electronics). March/April/May 2011: 'ROMANCE'. November/December 2011/January 2012: 'BORN'. March/April/May 2012: 'INSENSATEZ'. ==Books == There have been several books written about experiences in ''Second Life''. ''Second Life Love''{{ cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/book/second-life-love/id466840476?mt=11 | title=Second Life Love (iTunes)}}{{ cite web |url= https://www.amazon.com/Second-Life-Love-Olsen/dp/1447816242/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1322436821&sr=1-3 | title=Second Life Love (Amazon)}} is example of such a book. It is a dialog between Per Olsen en Li Gang Qin about their partnership in Second Life. The authors have never seen each other in real life.
Other books include ''Second Life For Dummies''{{ cite web |url=https://www.amazon.ca/Second-Life-Dummies-Sarah-Robbins/dp/0470180250 | title=Second Life For Dummies (Amazon)}} by Sarah Robbins and Mark Bell, which was published in 2008 and provides assistance for new users of the virtual world, including basics, how to meet people, ideas for activities and places to visit, including how to access real life education in ''Second Life''. ==Second Life artists== === Annabeth Robinson === {{Main article|Annabeth Robinson}} Annabeth Robinson, or AngryBeth Shortbread, creates online performances or installations using Second Life. For example, Robinson contributed to the 'Kritical Works in SL' project in 2008 to create a sound installation called ''Ping Space''.{{cite journal|last=Doyle |first=Denise |title=Virtual Worlds and New Realms of Creativity: The Kritical Works in SL Project |journal=International Journal of Performance Arts and Digital Media |volume=4 |issue=2-3 |pages=137–153(17) |date=1 May 2008 |url=http://www.tulane.edu/~simon/misc/Mardi%20Gras%20Conference%20Proceedings%202009/Session%202/Doyle.pdf |accessdate=2011-10-25 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} This was a piece of work that involved two cubes reverberating sound from each other which would only happen when one cube was 300 ft above the other. Other such work can be found at the [[Annabeth Robinson]] page. === Garrett Lynch === {{Main article|Garrett Lynch}} Garrett Lynch is an Irish new media artist working with networked technologies in a variety of forms including online art, installation, performance and writing. Since 2008 he has created a series of installation and performance works dealing with ideas of identity and place as they relate to networked spaces. In these works Lynch explores the "real" and the "virtual" through the transposing of his own identity to virtual worlds such as [[Second life|Second Life]] without any attempt to masquerade or imagine a new identity. This process involves the use of his real name for his "representation" or avatar, word play that references his names origins as both real and Irish and the use of a [[sandwich board]] prop stating this that is worn continuously. In 2010/2011 he was artist in residence at [[HUMlab]], Yoshikaze Up-in-the-Air Residency.{{cite web | url=http://yoshikaze.blogspot.co.uk/search/label/Garrett%20Lynch | title=Yoshikaze Up-in-the-Air Residency | author= |work= | publisher=Yoshikaze Up-in-the-Air Residency | accessdate=18 May 2012}}{{cite web | url=http://blog.humlab.umu.se/?p=2739 | title=HUMlab weblog announcing new artist | author=Jim Barrett |date=29 November 2010 |work= | publisher=HUMlab | accessdate=18 May 2012}} Outcomes of the residence have since been published as an artists book and an article in Metaverse Creativity (Volume 2, Number 2).{{cite journal |last=Lynch |first=Garrett |title=A Metaverse Art Residency: ‘Garrett Lynch Yoshikaze "Up-in-the-air" Second Life Residency’ |journal=Metaverse Creativity |volume=2 |issue=2 |year=2012 |pages=163–181 |publisher=Intellect Journals}} Currently Lynch has and is currently performing with a custom-built scale reproduction of his Second Life "representations" sandwich board. This has been worn at a number of exhibitions and performances.{{cite web|url=http://www.dorkbot.org/dorkbotcardiff/meeting03.htm |title=Dorkbot Cardiff #3 |author= |date=14 July 2011 |work= |publisher=Dorkbot Cardiff |accessdate=18 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017083234/http://www.dorkbot.org/dorkbotcardiff/meeting03.htm |archivedate=17 October 2013 }}{{cite web | url=http://decemberlab.wordpress.com/2011/05/29/being-19th-28th-may-2011/ | title=Being | author= |date=19–28 May 2011 |work= | publisher=DecemberLab | accessdate=17 May 2012}} === Gleman Jun === Gleman Jun is an Italian artist in Second Life. In the dynamic effects of colors, lights and transparencies, he expresses his creativity in a constantly evolving and transforming himself. In his case, a work of art is composed of two different elements: vision and technique. "Vision" is the image that passes through his mind suddenly. "Technique" is the experience that allows the memory to translate the vision into a "real" and shareable object. === Second Front === Second Front is the first performance art group of [[Second life|Second Life]]. Founded in 2006, its current seven-member troupe includes Gazira Babeli (Italy), Yael Gilks (London), [[Bibbe Hansen]] (New York), Doug Jarvis (Victoria), [[Scott Kildall]] (San Francisco), Patrick Lichty (Chicago) and Liz Solo (St. Johns). Second Front members collaborate remotely and their performances have been shown live in New York, Los Angeles, Moscow, Brussels, Berlin, Vancouver and many other cities. The group has been written about in publications including [[ArtForum]], [[Art in America]], Realtime Arts (Australia), Exibart (Italy) and Digital Art, (Second Edition) by [[Christiane Paul (curator)]]. ==Second Life Art group== SL Art is one of the most popular art groups in Second Life. Its goal is to recognize the art in virtual worlds at the same level of [[Outline of the visual arts|visual art]] in real life. There are several second Life publications that work to promote Second Life Art, including Windlight Magazine,http://wwwwindlightmagazine.com{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} the SL Newser,http://slnewser.blogspot.ca/p/meet-crew.html and the SL Enquirer.http://www.slenquirer.com/2015/10/spotlight-on-halloween-mage-dean-lawson.html ==References== {{reflist}} {{Second Life}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arts In Second Life}} [[Category:Second Life]] [[Category:Arts databases]] [[Category:Virtual art museums and galleries]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]]

[[Image:Bateman365.png|thumb|250px|Scott Bateman and Colleen AF Venable discuss that 'Every Day is a Damn Holiday' in a Scott Bateman cartoon.]] '''Bateman 365''' is a project initiated by [[Scott Bateman]] in August 2005 to emulate the idea presented by the [https://web.archive.org/web/20060515152653/http://www.brickfilms.com/phpBB2/viewtopic.php?t=8946 24 Hour Animation Contest] on the scale of one year. It utilizes a number of characters Bateman developed for his syndicated [[political cartoons]] and other works, as well as snippets from life in [[New York City]] and audio commentaries from third parties.
== Recurring characters (usually voiced by Scott Bateman) == *'''Blind Mango Jehosophat:''' a satirization of [[Blind Willie McTell]] and [[Blind Lemon Jefferson]]. *'''Bobo the Bear:''' a "cute", [[Nihilism|nihilistic]] bear. *'''Bob the Damn Bunny:''' a [[lewd]] bunny rabbit. *'''Scurvy Steve, Pirate Accountant'''
== Real life voices and subject sources == *[[George W. Bush]]: a number of speeches by Bush are satirized. *[[Colleen AF Venable]] *[[Laura Krafft]] *[[Terry Bain]]

{{other uses2|Pantokrator}} [[Image:Christ_Pantocrator_mosaic_from_Hagia_Sophia_2744_x_2900_pixels_3.1_MB.jpg|thumb|Jesus Christ Pantocrator (Detail from the [[deesis]] [[mosaic]] in [[Hagia Sophia]], [[Istanbul]])]]
In [[Christian iconography]], '''Christ Pantocrator''' is a specific [[depiction of Jesus|depiction of Christ]]. ''Pantocrator'' or ''Pantokrator'' ({{lang-grc-gre|Χριστὸς Παντοκράτωρ}})<ref>{{LSJ|pantokra/twr|παντοκράτωρ|ref}}</ref> is, used in this context, derived from of one of many [[Names of God in Judaism|names of God]] in Judaism.
When the [[Hebrew Bible]] was translated into Greek as the [[Septuagint]], ''Pantokrator'' was used both for ''YHWH Sabaoth'' "[[Lord of Hosts]]"<ref>[[:s:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/First and Second Books of Kings|2 Kings]] ([[Books of Samuel|2 Samuel]]) 7:8 and [[Book of Amos|Amos]] 3:13</ref> and for ''[[El Shaddai]]'' "[[God Almighty]]".<ref>[[Book of Job|Job]] 5:17, 15:25 and 22:25</ref> In the [[New Testament]], ''Pantokrator'' is used once by [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]] ({{bibleverse|2|Cor|6:18|KJV}}) and nine times in the [[Book of Revelation]]: {{bibleverse-nb||Rev|1:8|KJV}}, {{bibleverse-nb||Rev|4:8|KJV}}, {{bibleverse-nb||Rev|11:17|KJV}}, {{bibleverse-nb||Rev|15:3|KJV}}, {{bibleverse-nb||Rev|16:7|KJV}}, {{bibleverse-nb||Rev|16:14|KJV}}, {{bibleverse-nb||Rev|19:6|KJV}}, {{bibleverse-nb||Rev|19:15|KJV}}, and {{bibleverse-nb||Rev|21:22|KJV}}. The references to God and Christ in Revelation are at times interchangeable, ''Pantokrator'' appears to be reserved for God except, perhaps, in 1:8.
==Meaning== [[File:Christ Pantokrator, Cathedral of Cefalù, Sicily.jpg|thumb|Christ Pantocrator mosaic in [[Byzantine art|Byzantine style]] from the [[Cefalù Cathedral]], [[Sicily]]]] The most common translation of ''Pantocrator'' is "Almighty" or "All-powerful". In this understanding, ''Pantokrator'' is a compound word formed from the Greek words {{lang|grc|πᾶς}}, ''{{transl|grc|pas}}'' (<small>[[genitive|GEN]]</small> {{lang|grc|παντός}} ''{{transl|grc|pantos}}''), i.e. "all"<ref>{{LSJ|pa{{=}}s1|πᾶς|ref}}</ref> and {{lang|grc|κράτος}}, ''{{transl|grc|kratos}},'' i.e. "strength", "might", "power".<ref>{{LSJ|kra/tos1|κράτος|ref}}</ref> This is often understood in terms of potential power; i.e., ability to do anything, [[omnipotence]].
Another, more literal translation is "Ruler of All" or, less literally, "Sustainer of the World". In this understanding, Pantokrator is a compound word formed from the Greek for "all" and the verb meaning "To accomplish something" or "to sustain something" ({{lang|grc|κρατεῖν}}, ''{{transl|grc|kratein}}''). This translation speaks more to God's actual power; i.e., God does everything (as opposed to God can do everything).
The Pantokrator, largely an Eastern Orthodox or Eastern Catholic theological conception, is less common by that name in Western (Roman) Catholicism and largely unknown to most Protestants. In the West the equivalent image in art is known as [[Christ in Majesty]], which developed a rather different [[iconography]].
''Christ Pantocrator'' has come to suggest Christ as a mild but stern, all-powerful judge of humanity.
==Iconography== [[File:Spas vsederzhitel sinay.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Christ Pantocrator (Sinai)|The oldest known icon of ''Christ Pantocrator'']], [[encaustic painting|encaustic on panel]] ([[Saint Catherine's Monastery]]). The two different facial expressions on either side may emphasize Christ's [[Hypostatic union|two natures]] as fully God and fully human.<ref>''God's Human Face: The Christ-Icon'' by Christoph Schoenborn (1994) {{ISBN|0-89870-514-2}} page 154</ref><ref>''Sinai and the Monastery of St. Catherine'' by John Galey (1986) {{ISBN|977-424-118-5}} page 92</ref>]] The icon of Christ Pantokrator is one of the most common religious images of Orthodox Christianity. Generally speaking, in [[Byzantine art|Medieval eastern roman]] church art and architecture, an [[icon]]ic mosaic or fresco of Christ Pantokrator occupies the space in the central dome of the church, in the half-dome of the [[apse]], or on the [[nave]] vault. Some scholars (Latourette 1975: 572) consider the Pantocrator a Christian adaptation of images of Zeus, such as the great [[Statue of Zeus at Olympia|statue of Zeus enthroned at Olympia]]. The development of the earliest stages of the icon from Roman Imperial imagery is easier to trace.<ref>Eduard Syndicus; ''Early Christian Art''; p. 96–99; Burns & Oates, London, 1962. Hall pp. 78–80; James Hall, ''A History of Ideas and Images in Italian Art'', pp. 91–97, 1983, John Murray, London, {{ISBN|0-7195-3971-4}}</ref>
The image of Christ Pantocrator was one of the first [[images of Jesus|images of Christ]] developed in the [[Early Christianity|Early Christian Church]] and remains a central icon of the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]. In the half-length image, Christ holds the [[New Testament]] in his left hand and makes the gesture of teaching or of [[blessing]] with his right. The typical Western [[Christ in Majesty]] is a full-length icon. In the early [[Middle Ages]], it usually presented Christ in a [[mandorla]] or other geometric frame, surrounded by the [[Four Evangelists]] or their symbols.
[[Christ Pantocrator (Sinai)|The oldest known surviving example]] of the icon of Christ Pantocrator was painted in [[Encaustic painting|encaustic]] on panel in the sixth or seventh century, and survived the period of destruction of images during the [[Iconoclasm|Iconoclastic disputes]] that twice racked the Eastern church, 726 to 787 and 814 to 842. It was preserved in [[Saint Catherine's Monastery]], in the remote desert of the [[Sinai Peninsula|Sinai]].<ref>Manolis Chatzidakis and Gerry Walters, "An Encaustic Icon of Christ at Sinai", ''The Art Bulletin'' '''49'''.3 (September 1967) pp. 197–208.</ref> The gessoed panel, finely painted using a wax medium on a wooden panel, had been coarsely overpainted around the face and hands at some time around the thirteenth century. When the overpainting was cleaned in 1962, the ancient image was revealed to be a very high-quality icon, probably produced in [[Constantinople]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}
The icon, traditionally half-length when in a [[semi-dome]],<ref>Otherwise the size of the figure would have to be greatly reduced to avoid the head appearing at the flattening top of the semi-dome.</ref> which became adopted for panel icons also, depicts Christ fully frontal with a somewhat melancholy and stern aspect, with the right hand raised in blessing or, in the early encaustic panel at Saint Catherine's Monastery, the conventional rhetorical gesture that represents teaching. The left hand holds a closed book with a richly decorated cover featuring the [[Cross]], representing the [[Gospel]]s. An icon where Christ has an open book is called "Christ the Teacher", a variant of the Pantocrator. Christ is bearded, his brown hair centrally parted, and his head is surrounded by a [[Halo (religious iconography)|halo]]. The icon is usually shown against a gold background comparable to the gilded grounds of mosaic depictions of the Christian emperors.
Often, the [[Christogram|name of Christ]] is written on each side of the halo, as [[ICXC|IC and XC]]. Christ's fingers are depicted in a pose that represents the letters IC, X and C, thereby making the [[Christogram]] ''ICXC'' (for "Jesus Christ"). The IC is composed of the Greek characters [[iota]] (Ι) and [[lunate sigma]] (C; instead of Σ, ς)—the first and last letters of 'Jesus' in Greek ({{lang|el|Ἰησοῦς}}); in XC the letters are [[Chi (letter)|chi]] (Χ) and again the lunate sigma—the first and last letters of 'Christ' in Greek ({{lang|el|Χριστός}}).
In many cases, Christ has a [[cruciform halo]] inscribed with the letters Ο Ω Ν, i.e. {{lang|grc| ὁ ὢν}} [[I Am that I Am#Hellenistic Judaism|"He Who Is"]].

Богородица,Битола).jpg|Roof [[fresco]] of Christ Pantocrator, Nativity of the Theotokos Church, [[Bitola]], Macedonia File:Christ Pantocrator (Church of St. Alexander Nevsky, Belgrade).jpg|Christ Pantocrator in the Orthodox [[Church of St. Alexander Nevsky, Belgrade]] </gallery>

[[File:70-м антенна П-2500 (РТ-70).jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[RT-70]] in [[Yevpatoria]]]]'''Cosmic Call''' was the name of two sets of interstellar radio messages that were sent from [[RT-70]] in [[Yevpatoria]], [[Crimea]] in 1999 (Cosmic Call 1) and 2003 (Cosmic Call 2) to various nearby stars. The messages were designed with noise-resistant format and characters.
The project was funded by Team Encounter, Charlie Chafer (CEO) <ref name=smthsonian>{{cite journal| url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/how-couple-guys-built-most-ambitious-alien-outreach-project-ever-180960473/?no-ist | title= How a Couple of Guys Built the Most Ambitious Alien Outreach Project Ever, History of Cosmic Calls |author= Michael Chorost | journal= Smithsonian | date=September 26, 2016}}</ref> a [[Texas]]-based startup, which went out of business in 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cs.astronomy.com/asycs/forums/p/17428/295175.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515102750/http://cs.astronomy.com/asycs/forums/p/17428/295175.aspx |archivedate=2009-05-15 |df= }}</ref>
Both transmissions were at ~150 kW, 5.01 GHz ([[Frequency-shift_keying | FSK]] +/-24 kHz).<ref name=CC2>{{ cite web | url=http://www.cplire.ru/html/ra&sr/irm/CosmicCall-2003/index.html | title = Synthesis and Transmission of Cosmic Call 2003 Interstellar Radio Message | author=Richard Braastad, Team Encounter, USA, Alexander Zaitsev, IRE RAS, Russia}}}</ref>
==Message structure==
Each '''Cosmic Call 1''' session had the following structure. The Scientific Part (DDM, BM, AM, and ESM) was sent three times (at 100 bit/s),<ref name=RC1>[http://www.cplire.ru/html/ra&sr/irm/report-1999.html "Broadcast for Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence from Evpatoria Deep Space Center" Report on Cosmic Call 1999]</ref> and the Public Part (PP) was sent once (at 2000 bit/s),<ref name=RC1/> according to the following arrangement:
:DDM → BM → AM → ESM → DDM → BM → AM → ESM → DDM → BM → AM → ESM → PP,
where DDM is the [http://www.plover.com/misc/Dumas-Dutil/messages.pdf Dutil-Dumas Message], created by Canadian scientists [[Yvan Dutil]] and [[Stéphane Dumas (astrophysicist)|Stéphane Dumas]], BM is the Braastad Message, AM is the [[Arecibo Message]], and ESM is the Encounter 2001 Staff Message.<ref name=RC1/>
Each '''Cosmic Call 2''' session in 2003 had the following structure:
:DDM2 → DDM2 → DDM2 → AM → AM → AM → BIG → BIG → BIG → BM → ESM → PP,
where DDM2 is modernized DDM (aka [[Interstellar Rosetta Stone]], ISR), BIG is [[Bilingual Image Glossary]].<ref name=CC2/> All but the PP were transmitted at 400 bit/s<ref name=CC2/>
The ISR was 263,906 bits; BM, 88,687 bits, AM, 1,679 bits; BIG was 12 binary images 121,301 bits; ESM 24,899 bits. Total = 500,472 bits for 53 minutes. PP was 220 megabytes and sent at a rate of 100,000 bit/s for 11 hours total.<ref name=CC2/>
==Stars targeted== The messages were sent to the following stars:<ref name="cplire.ru">[http://www.cplire.ru/rus/ra&sr/VAK-2004.html Передача и поиски разумных сигналов во Вселенной<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

[[Image:EchternachDancingProcession.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Dancers in the procession, May 2008]] The '''dancing procession of Echternach''' is an annual [[Roman Catholic]] dancing procession held at [[Echternach]], in eastern [[Luxembourg]]. Echternach's is the last traditional dancing procession in [[Europe]].
The procession is held every [[Whit Tuesday]]<ref>go to [https://archive.org/web/web.php WayBackMachine] enter: <nowiki>{{cite web |url=http://www.luxembourg.co.uk/dancproc.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-06-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514151612/http://www.luxembourg.co.uk/dancproc.html |archivedate=2008-05-14 |df= }}</nowiki>, select the 14th of April 2012 for ''The Dancing Procession of Echternach''</ref> around the streets of the [[List of cities in Luxembourg|city]] of Echternach. It honours [[Willibrord]], the [[patron saint]] of Luxembourg, who established the [[Abbey of Echternach]]. Echternach has developed a strong tourism industry centred on the procession, which draws many thousands of tourists and [[pilgrim]]s from around the world. The procession is inscribed in 2010 as ''hopping procession of Echternach'' on the [[UNESCO]] [[UNESCO Lists of Intangible Cultural Heritage|Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity]].<ref>[http://www.unesco.org/culture/ich/index.php?lg=en&pg=00011&RL=00392 The hopping procession of Echternach]</ref>
==The procession==
The event <ref name="organisation">[http://www.willibrord.lu/spip.php?article50 Participation, course of the procession and organisation]</ref> begins in the morning at the bridge over the [[Sauer|River Sauer]], with a sermon delivered by the parish priest (formerly by the [[abbot]] of the [[monastery]]). "Willibrordus-Brauverein" officials put together the procession, forming several dozen alternating groups of musicians and pilgrims. The procession then moves through the town streets towards the [[basilica]], a distance of about {{convert|1.5|km|mi}}. While the musicians play the "Sprangprozessioùn" tune–a traditional melody, not entirely unlike an Irish jig or reel, that has been handed down through the centuries–the pilgrims, in rows of four or five abreast and holding the ends of white handkerchiefs, "dance" or "jump" from left to right and thus slowly move forward. Because of the numbers of pilgrims attending, it is well after midday before the last of the dancers has reached the church. A large number of priests, nuns, and monks also accompany the procession, and not infrequently there are several [[bishop]]s as well. On arrival at the church, the dance is continued past the tomb of Saint Willibrord, which stands in the [[crypt]] beneath the [[high altar]]. [[Litany|Litanies]] and prayers in the Saint's honour are recited, and the event concludes with a benediction of the sacrament.
In the past, the dancing procession has adopted other forms. At one stage the pilgrims would take three steps forward and two steps backwards, thus taking five steps in order to advance one; at another stage the pilgrims would repeatedly stop at the sound of the bell donated by [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Maximilian]], falling to their knees before moving forward a few more steps. Again, pilgrims would crawl under a stone, facing the cross of St. Willibrord. A 'cattle-bell dance' used to take place in front of the cross, which was erected on the marketplace; this dance was prohibited in 1664.
==History==
Willibrord's Abbey of Echternach was a major Christian centre in the [[Middle Ages]], and maintained a famous [[library]] and [[scriptorium]]. However, it owes its modern fame to the quaint dancing procession. This aspect of the cult of the saint may be traced back almost to the date of his death; among the stream of pilgrims to his tomb in the abbey church have been [[Holy Roman Emperor|Emperors]] [[Charlemagne]], [[Lothair I]], [[Conrad II, Holy Roman Emperor|Conrad]], and later Maximilian (in 1512).
[[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] historians are reluctant to ascribe any pre-Christian antecedents to the dancing procession, and claim only that its origin cannot be stated with certainty. There might be elements of [[Paganism|pagan]] cult, such as the ones that were criticised by [[Saint Eligius]] in the 7th century. Documents of the fifteenth century speak of it as a long-established custom at that time, and a similar "dancing" procession, which used to take place in the small town of [[Prüm]], in the [[Eifel]], was documented as early as 1342. Legends are told that relate the dancing procession to an averted plague or offer a fable about a condemned fiddler, but the dancing procession to the saint's tomb is an annual ceremony done as an act of [[penance]] on behalf of afflicted relations and especially in order to avert [[epilepsy]], [[Chorea (disease)|Saint Vitus Dance]], or [[convulsion]]s.
The procession took place annually without intermission until 1777. There has been an uneasy relationship with the church hierarchy; in 1777, the music and dancing of the 'dancing saints' were forbidden by Archbishop Wenceslas, who declared that there should only be a pilgrim's procession, and, in 1786, [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Joseph II]] abolished the procession altogether. Attempts were made to revive it ten years later, and, although the French Revolution effectually prevented it, it was recommenced in 1802, and has continued ever since. In 1826, the government tried to change the day to a Sunday, but, since 1830, it has always taken place on [[Whit Tuesday]], a traditional day that, significantly, bears no direct relation to St. Willibrord himself.
